Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could stir this gentle tempest sea,
Nor lend the moon such trembling gold
Upon my harbor, harrowed, cold.
Your voice —ordam lights fires at dawn,
When shadows line the labor'd lawn;
Far sweeter perfumed hopes awake,
And with each secret vow I make,
Still beats my heart for you alone,
Through softest dusk and chiseled stone.
Upon this vow I rest my soul:
Nothing but you can make me whole.
The world unweaves when we must part—
Dear love, you are the only art.

This anger burns deep within: a forged and fevered art—  
A furnace painting sunrise red inside the grieving heart.  
It glimmers, shards beneath the skin, unrepentantly alive,  
Fueled by years and faultlines marked where tumbleweeds survive.

Lisps of smoke in every word I let escape or stay,
Grooves in every memory that bruise but won’t decay—
Yet catharsis grows in darkness, bone and oxygen heal slow:
The alchemy of sorrow is the glory angst bestows.

instance_metrics.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
My heart strides bold against the chill—
A lantern held in mystery's dark,
Lighting where longing shapes its will.

Fain would I barter the fiercest star
If only joy played court with thee;
No golden gift would rival bright,
What wonder spreads if near you be.

In silent rooms of shadow’s sweep,
Thy whisper settles on my chest.
Each breath recall'd, each moment sworn,
Marks thee the compass in my breast.

Dear love, against bleak doubt I know
No sum but what you dare bestow.

instance_metrics.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I lend voice to silent plea.
Twas not for fleeting sun or star
My hopes so great and wishes are,
But for the gentle breath we hold,
For hearts entwined as tales of old.

Your laughter lights the darkest hours,
The sweetest taste the breaking hours.
No crown of gold nor rare decree
Could equal what you grant to me.

Dear love, it's at your feet I prove:
There’s nothing giften like your love.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would stir my soul through cloud and rain;
The velvet dark, the restless sea—
All soften in thy light again.

No fleeting dream the years could give
Transcends my hope and reverie,
For what is joy, unless I live
Wholly, undivided, for thee?

Speak once thy name, my evening sun—
Of all the yesterdays begun,
Not one shines more bright or free
Than this vague dawn you cast on me.

desire in every breath; still I remain,

that warms my ribs and comes again and again.

No blossom bold, nor jewel to admire,
could teach this thirst a sharper agony
than waiting for you; all brands inspire
a hush that aches for nothing less than thee.

Upheld by promises unclad and light,
belief bows gently to your memory,
and every day the stars collapse to write
Dear love: there is nothing less than thee.

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Whispered through epochs by churchgoers’ bell.
A promise of wisdom, a warming embrace,
But beneath the green twists, a treacherous face.

Truth is not simple, nor history kind,
Dual threads ever knotted in the tapes of our mind.
Was it folly, desire, or fate at the start?
And who today wears the bruise on their heart?

But serpents still slither and fruit still shines red,
A lure of the knowledge from which we have fed.
And as long as tales pass down quivering spine,
We’ll hallow the shadows in words like divine.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
A beacon through the darkest night,  
In lonely hours my hopes have grown  
Clinging gentle to Thy light.  

When ebbing tides dare wane my soul,  
And starless wonders cross the skies,  
I hear Thy whisper make me whole—  
Felt within where doubt abides.  

Forevermore I’ll shape my days  
In silence counted sweet as prayer,  
Attuned to only ancient praise,  
Secure, O Lord, Thou findest there.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
My soul for Thee, deep-rooted, longs—  
Amidst the hush, my spirit’s grown,  
Warming softly with angel songs.  

Through winding paths or tempest wild,  
No other hand I wish to hold—  
Adorn me in Thy mercies, child,  
Enfold me gently from the cold.  

In seeking Thee—this gracious throne—  
My song ascends from flesh to bone.  
O faith most faithful, carved in stone:  
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone; 
Upon Thy name my heart is stayed— 
No shifting sands nor turning stone 
Shall steal the trust that faith has made.

Through barren fields or splintered dreams,

Still Thou art morning’s golden beam,
Still haven through the trembling day.

Unnumbered stars fierce winds may strew, 
Or time dissolve each promised year:
Yet let the world become anew—
My God remains unfailing, near.

Everyone has a fear shrouded deep inside,
Soft shadows that lurk where memories abide.
In daytime, smiles mask the cracks and seams,
Yet at midnight, they haunt us, jumping through dreams.

A tremor in voices that struggle to speak.
We all wear our armor, pretend we don’t waver,
Eyes scanning horizons for dragons to slay or savor.
Perhaps it’s failure or change, or silence profound,
The grief of what’s lost or needs to be found.
Each hope that we wake with, each wish that we share,
Lends courage in places where fear plants despair,
So hand me your sorrow and I’ll lend you mine,
In candor together—as vessels, confined,
For sweeter than triumph untouched by dread,
Is a comfort discovered where insecurities tread.

Yet in these hallowed moments, between hush and shout,
Our trembling souls learn what resilience is about.
Fear brushes our shoulders, shows what aches to defend—
Family, hope, new beginnings without bitter end.
To stare straight ahead as the old patterns crack,
Turns solace and strength from what makes us crack.
We gather together—in whispers or song—
To prove in our fright, we also belong.
Everyone bears a shadow behind bright cheer—
Admitting in one breath: "Yes,
everyone has a fear."

My God, how many are my fears!  
A frail hand trembling on the doorknob of morning.  
Each thought, a shadow twined about my heart,

Will thunder shake my fragile home to splinters,  
Or memory betray the kind illusions of rest?  
Even my silence multiplies them: spiderleg slow,  
they creep in shoes, flickering before I've guessed.  

Yet, amid the hushed outrage, courage grows unseen—  
Soft chrysalis balancing hope’s eggshell white luster.  
As birds rehearse the braver cords of unseen flight,  
I gather faith behind ribs bright-tentered.  
Tremble, heart, though fretted by fear’s swarm.  
Remind yourself each shadow wanes at dawn,  
If even as one bold exhale storms fresh toward birth.  
I have been afraid; I wake again—emboldened to go on.

My God, how many are my fears—
A rising tide within the chest,
Relentless as the circling years,
Unbidden phantoms rob my rest.

They cluster thick as evening clouds,
Obscuring every star with doubt.
And when harsh silence wraps me 'round,
Whispered worry cannot drown out.

Yet with dawn's slow, luminous brush,
I find your mercy quietly appears:
Against the tally of rush and hush,
You offer calm upon my tears.

Each fret a prayer frail but clear—
To hope anyway: still persevere.

If my ear’s companion to your gauze or your thunder
Perhaps my tongue won’t utter banal plunder.
In small rooms or abroad upon confused faces
Let my habit be first silence—a sacred basis;
Persuaded by ripples you leave on calm air—
May my speech build, true, from my true patient care.
I address you, living root at my door :
"If I consent to know you, will I fear reversal no more?"

Beneath the weeping olive boughs,
A silence fell like heavy shrouds;
Came Christ The Lord, with step assured,
Not bearing peace, but bringing sword.

He cleaved the night, and broke apart
Complacent ties, the quiet heart;
His fury burned, his words did shine,
Sharp-edged, dividing wrong from right.

Peace was tossed like autumn leaf—
False comfort for unyielding grief;
Brothers fissured at his word,
Seeking a threshold to be cured.

Upon this cross of riven time,
He measured theft against the crime.
Not all who knocked could walk inside;  
The narrow gate alone the guide.

So echoed down the blood-stained years—
The angels singing with shedding tears.
Christ with sword from battle torn:
Forsaken hope, yet world reborn.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A gentle dusk fell close and sober:
Hushed footsteps left a braided trail
Along the hills and wintry vale.

From silent eaves the softness spilled
On crooked wood and fields that stilled,
A gleaming breath on wire and stone,
Restoring grace to tired bones.

Yet through this universal white,
A thousand windows yield to light,
Bright memories, like embers fed,
Mid stories told and words unsaid.

It snowed and snowed, and none could mar
The silent reign from peak to star,
Whole world enfolded source to clover—
It snowed. It snowed. The shadows hover.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,

as if the world's laborious run
keeps time to your presumptuous tune.
Why stir my sleeping hours pell-mell,
throw curtain-light on tangled hair?
Do lovers need your loudest knell
to swear all daylight truth or dare?
The world revolves; you think you're king,
yet small pleas anchor you right here.
Just let your chariot offer spring
to those bereft and needy, dear!

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,  
Your golden fingers force the day begun.  
Veils of shadows, gently torn,  
Trembling as new hours are born.  
Through curtains thin and streets undone,  
Dreamers hide from work to be spun.
O stubborn mark at horizon's rise,  
Gazer blind with knavish eyes,  
Intruder bright on lovers’ rest,  
You march unfelt and unaddressed—  
Why summon chimes to sever sleep?  
Let warmth delay where night runs deep.  
Your impatience cannot abide,  
Nor heed the dreams my heart would hide.  
Flare your treason, crown the sky:  
Yet for all your tyranny, hours pass by—  
Mortal is toil before time’s run.  
Still, who but you lets laughing day be spun?

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life,
Each carving patterns in our days.
Some teach us courage in the storms,
Others quietly slip away.

In woven threads of memory,
Are handshakes, laughs, and sudden tears,
Journeys launched by glances glossed,
But lessons settled deep for years.

The journey holds no maps defined,
No fixed arrival with pearl or crown—
But bit by bit, these meetings shape
The tale we write as we move on.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life;
 Rivers may fork and then unite, 
Their babble marks upon our banks—
A fleeting taste of other nights.

In every harbored heart, a harbor—
A ship docking for cocoa or song—
Some will unpack both wonder and longing,
While others simply float along.

Between greetings stitched in morning light 
And partings painted in distant dusk,
Connections bloom amidst the stir 
of stories written for just us.

How strange, the gentle tapestry woven—
Not with thread, but touch and talk—
Carrying, in the weave of travel,
A shimmering memory as we walk.

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Half crumbled by many a day:
Its doorway bloomed wild mossy green,
And nettles had claimed all between.
A shadow of summers gone by
Hung softly by eaves neath the sky,
Twilight knit webs in the thatch brown,
While ivy reached up and back down.
Forgotten but gentled by years,
Still holding old laughter and tears,
This dwelling, so quiet and mild—
Once echoed the romp of a child.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Its roof caved in from rays and rain,
Violets blooming at their own sweet will
Tracked along the sagging sill…
Shadows lingered, creeping through dust,
Remembering hands long gone to rust:
A russet bird whistled by the door—
As if merged with the voices before.
Hello and farewell curled like smoke,
In the hush where my heart awoke:
That humble cottage crumbling away—
A grave for memories pressed like clay.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay,  
Set deep in a prism of green,  
Windows agleam with sweet sighs of the day,  
Humming secrets they’d silently glean.  
Cobweb-veiled door knelt low with the time,  
Ledges grown soft under lichen and vine:  
Yet through the slow hush lived a hint of delight—  
A glow that clung quietly, curling with light.  
No grandeur was fashioned for none to commend,  
Still warmth on those stones would quietly send  
Hopes upon fields that slumbered with dew,  
As voices faded, and quietly grew.

instance_metrics.response:
I saw an old cottage of clay—  
Its chimney shaped crooked, askew,  
Where embers once danced and laughed at the breeze,  
Whispers with sky in the blue.  
Limp daffodils bowed in the grass deep,  
The path twisted softly and bright;  
Tales padlocked behind lichen lace, under heap  
Of sorrow and ghostly delight.  
I listened: Through creak and the hush before night,  
Old hopes took the walls as they may;  
I stayed till the starlight had simmered away  
Beside that small cottage of clay.

We meet many people in life,
Each etched by their seasons and scars,
A mosaic alike converging—a brief
Shuffle on trains under dimming stars.
Their laughter is caught in the avenue winds,
Stories thick with secret grieves;
Poets killed time before time begins,
Singers left music on autumn's slim leaves.
Yet not all remain as our paths cross and twine;
Some pass in soft glimmers through our days.
Ordinary moments, intangible and fine,
Still shape the journeys in serenest haze.
We meet many people in life's gentle stream—
Some walk forever within our dream.

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life,
Threads weaving a tapestry bright.
Strangers glancing, sharing a glance,
Friends made in moments that prance
Like sunlight through a fence—
dribs of kindness, offense, and sense.
Some stray away like kissed-off stars—
others settle in perpetual jars,
Memories staggered bloomed with hope;
lifelong, fleeting, learning to cope.
That passing face, that gentle word—
each touch a tale, a seed that stirred!
Wise or foolish, aware or naïve,
We gather imprints each hour we breathe.
We meet many people, through closeness or strife;
each leaving their color along the road of our life.

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life, 
Some swift as raindrops on glass— 
Moments that echo, whispers by night, 
Souls who pause, then rise and pass. 
Smiling teachers along frail bridges, 
Anchors heavy we dare not free; 
Kindred and strangers, like distant ridges 
In silhouette, unknown, yet close to me. 
Conversations spiral, swift and rare— 
A glance, laughter, or complaint we share. 
We meet many people beginning anew; 
Most drift away, remembered by few. 
Yet whether tornado or butterfly light, 
Each prints a memory hard or slight.

Weather forecast in Kabul: the morning shimmers,
going above minarets with blurring light;
earlier sky swept empty – soft as silver evoke –
glaces off apricot trees crusted in wintry frost.
Children leap puddles cut open in cracked clay,
soldiering make-believe with tattered hands that grasp
yester wind-spun bread and suggestions –
will the sun parade up or slink into mist/plume?
In tea houses filled with patient hush awaits,
yellow bulbs, brewing secrets inside hollowed cups,
old men predict the tempo by crow flights,
one eye always against unpredictable spine-of-cloud.
Forecast blows and erases like northern wind,
but today, the anticipation is softly honest:
suncast scattered, brief rains—not always darkness falls—
yearning in Kabul seeps into forecast,
a single hope for thaw left after discordant years.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

instance_metrics.response:
Weather forecast in Kabul:
Grey drapes the solitary slope, stitched
by fast bleak wind that scrims the mountains see-
not even carnations awake in cracks between the chilled concrete.
Bazaars echo under slate-smothered morning cloud,
environs plum with memory—dust tight against cumin and tea leaves.
Sonorous calls fill alleys glazed by motif far and vanished,
as shopkeepers weigh inside patchwork awnings what carry this sky anew.
Inside narrow homes—palms draped
over cups seething small steam—the radio forecaster’s voice cuts static:
“A chance of gentle snow, suggestive haze for dreaming.”
—children press against windowlight,
or boots tout streams folding yesterday downtrodden zones
with welcome difference just one white singing—blur; uncertain—,
Weather broods, refugee to itself, always lover and always friend—under Kabul: sympathetic to cautious hearts jangled by soil and change.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

instance_metrics.response:
Weather Forecast in Kabul: the sky a folded paper,
estimation held in sun-drenched hands—
birds zigzag declarations atop battered lampposts.
In Baba Mountain’s restless sleep, the purple wanes
and winter writes her secrets in slow drizzle and dust—
you can almost imagine fingertips etching cloud patterns
within fissures traced by aging prayer carpets,
as motorbikes grumble on cold and aching tarmac.
Tea walkers hide quiet wagers—is tonight thunder or stars?
Forecast reads half guesswork and half hope:
street vendors peer out of tarps, heavy with last orange,
a face learns to scan light, decode a map for possible rainshowers or sun.
Towards dusk, shadows harmonize with static--
predicting soft grace Midmorning.
What do they know:
a million thin breaths curating both rumor and ritual,
drenched in a Kabul neither gray–nor blue–nor taupe.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

instance_metrics.response:
Weather forecast in Kabul. Between war scars and roof tiles
lingers a song of anticipation: perhaps rain, perhaps relief—
a bright haze faintly rises above crumbled flats, forgiving morning fate.
Newspapers flap under thin hands serving saffron chai, restless eyes
to veiled hills soaked ancient deep. The wind, stubborn but tender,
isthe bearer—sometimes kind, sometimes much less—
signaling to fresh-washed scarves trembling just shy of hope.
Old poets remember a season more regular: afternoons painting bazaars
in lush light, seedlings quivering free. A radio hums now in pauses—forest,
swelter? Frost, sunlight? Familiars laugh it off—Kabul, as ever—
still balancing thin gray lines, still citing temperature with prayers in dust.
Night and softness or sudden change, chance given word:
tomorrow’s forecast never only weather, a careful reading in clouds and hope.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

instance_metrics.response:
Weather forecast in Kabul: The sky scribbled in charcoals, hints of mystery soot settled atop congested domes. Air shivers down alleyways where secrets link to grandfather clocks. While mothers heft woolen shadows over their heads, above it fractures pale turquoise dragged straight from legend. Winds recite the tongue of stones—listen! Poppies tilt, roots reading ancient barometers. Inside worn courtyards, puddled silence pools: a girl in red searches the gauzed chill just to check if dawn falls dry.

Elsewhere, in backstreet stalls expecting rain—even clouds converse gently. Nomads sipping spiced-coffee draft future spells: Mild breeze, maybe, a speckle of promise, edges held loosely to sigh and thunder. For Kabul carries its own climate inside—confident memory glowing like coals, ready for puddles, maybe rays—always, tomorrow rides beneath any forecast as resilient as the people tracing daylight in dust.

instance_metrics.response:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Bright herald at the day’s begun,
Why with brash gold do you awake
Soft moments lovers wish to make?
Scatterer of secret dreams, why bring
Wingèd haste with every beam you swing?
Here beneath your gaze so bright,
We plead, relent and stretch the night —
Let dawn defer, let shadows run;
Grant hours left that love has won.
Yet onward climb, bend not our will—
In burning truth, no world stands still.
Chide as you must with fervent light,
We name you tyrant but court your sight.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why do you rise so soon each blinding day?
Electric through curtain slats you sneak, unravel warmth and secret play.
You ransom slumber from my dreamy moor,
Burning my window and battering my door.
Larger than worries I hid in the dark,
Tireless engraver, revealing stark
All hopes and truths spun gentle by night,
Now chased away in corridors of light.
Shadow for mercy, I fleeting implore —
Do you rush the clocks as well as our floor?
O persistent intruder across slow skies Give my shade a moment to whisper goodbyes.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun, how you pry/A wakeful eye into my shaded noon;/You tap restless fingers on tangled light/ And break raw-green echoes in wild monsoon./Relenting not, you chide wicker dreams,/Peel back stories with your burning hand;/Always too early with promises lush,/You chart my hours with firebrands. /Yet even you, for all your theft and grace/Cannot erase the wine of midnight fall; /In tender haste, your law enslaves, parking dawn/by my rain-dappled wall.

Day-bringer, your patience denied Weddings hid in nighttime hush, /Hearts revolting at early rise -- /Relentless sphere whose hours rush,/Love clings longer in shadowed disguise.

instance_metrics.response:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun, you barge across the sleeping plain—
Hauling golden engines of reverie,
Reluctant curtains stuffed with dawn’s complaint.
Peer through attic glass, through leafy years,
Summon work and gentle fears.
Braggart orb that jeers at drowsy youth,
You tip midnight’s secret truth, inciting day
to harvest rusted pockets of lost time.
Why be so insistent, assign blinkering light
to love-wearied rites and habits intertwined? 
Still, once, just once, stay curled on the horizon,
Bleave night on the windowsill: let shadow linger,
Cede the revolution that turns our weathered skin jeweled and gleaming... lazy for a minute more.

The daylight summons only you.

For youth once pilfered, leaves in timeless haze.

a remembering—soft, easy peace

a slowness that heals, while night steadily wheels.

At the highways of woes, where sadness is paved
With exit signs flickering hopes once so brave,
The distant horizon is murky with doubt,
Promises lost at the wrong, winding route.
The road splits to heartache at every turn,
In shadows, forgotten ambitions burn.
Yet somewhere, beyond painted lines full of lead,
Blooms laughter that mends where sorrow has bled.
We wander in silence, under uncertain sky—
Mapless, and waiting, questioning why.
But engines of courage keep humming and warm,
Guiding us forwardourcing not from the storm
But the pull of new sunrise, gentle and sly—
On highways of woes, some hope learns to fly.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

instance_metrics.response:
At the highways of woes, old engines groan,
Guideposts hunger for journeys unknown.
Flashing between solace and sorrows denied,
We trudge through rain-stained horizons, wide.
Every mile pebbles with memories lost,
Bound by the gravity of every life’s cost.
Yet in tail light reflections, quietly see
A promise: the hope surviving in me.
Unending the hum of wanderer’s pain,
But with each humble oar through this gravelly lane,
We steer for tomorrow’s fragile repose,
And bloom in the cracks at the highways of woes.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

instance_metrics.response:
At the highways of woes, our troubles conspire,
Night settles in like exhausted desire.
Mist hugs the fields as neon signs blink mad,
And the sky bears the scars of all times we were sad.
Rubber on shoulder, decision and dread:
Forward is easy, it's turning back that we dread.
Still somehow beneath even asphalt despair,
Dispatches of light stutter hope in the air.
We journey, each haunted by what lies behind,
At the highways of woes, no solace to find—
Yet the moon dressed in ember on ruined plateau,
Reminds there’s a way off each highway of woe.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

instance_metrics.response:
At the highways of woes the restless wind goads—
Empty echoes medaled with strangers' heavy loads.
We pass memorial bouquets grass-sprung from cracks,
Monuments gentle marking what's never coming back.
Traffic churns remembrances cloud-gray and hollow;
Exiting laughter too brittle to follow.
Under stoic-mile count sings a tired day's refrain,
Mining for reservoirs of will against the long rain.
If fortune is fuel, fate’s asphalt is cold—
Beyond toll plazas sympathy sleeps uncontrolled.
Yet a single-lamp kindness still bridges defeat;
Some serendipity lingers, defiant and sweet.
Down avenues bruise-shadowed with overgrown hope,
Find courage, hands steady, adjusting the scope:
Parallel’s not certain, detour’s not weak,
At the highway of woes, we search as we seek.

instance_metrics.response:
In the hush of trembling nighttime,
Storms assail, the earth grows faint;
A beacon burns with holy rhyme—
God is the refuge of His saints.

Above the brittle ache and worry,
He carves calm from ancient light,
Smiling peace against the hurry,
Holding hearts gasping with fright.

Upon these rocky roads and years,
Through deepest shade, relentless age—
Scarred prayers dissolve to bits of tears,
Yet underneath are hands to cage.

For weary is not withered, friend,
Trust as seasons turn profound;
Breath out your sighs—the walls ascend—
Sheltered, steadfast, safe and sound.

You who wander through wildest turning, hear—
Beyond murmuring winds and your soul’s absent light,
There stands a pillar resolute, drawing you near,
Roots planted deep in glowing midnight.

God is the refuge of His saints—a tower,
Lifted strong when shadows crawl,
A mantel when tempests threaten to devour,
A hand both gentle cradle and wall.

Fear not, though the mountains slip or oceans roar,
And sorrow’s trials circle like sand;
His song travels sure to your inner core:
Strength awaits in His steadfast hand.

A cup he drinks that comforts him when storms are nearly grown.  
The language of his morning prayer, the symbols carved with care.  
Clouds spill different rain upon us, yet compassion flows somewhere.

I value every color spun from life's assorted dreams,  
A woven earth's intention played in countless vibrant themes.  
They're fleets that journey onwards, carried softly in their need—  
I respect another man's religion, his color, or his creed.

May whispers from our varied seeds build larger shade beneath,  
A world less fractured, absence filled with love in silent wreath.   
With heart and hope standing guard, as soul finds common feed—  
I respect another man's promise, his new blossoming bead.

instance_metrics.response:
I respect, another man's religion, or color or creed,  
The book he holds sacred, the verses he reads.  
We meet at these crossroads—each different, all kin,  
Spark and spirit glowing, not separate within.

A shadow, a pigment, a name seldom known,  
Nature twists ribbons, raw beauty is sown.  
May the borders dissolve where acceptance should lead—  
Faith and face different, but family in need.

Lift up the edges. Sing soft in belief.  
Find kindness in differences, mercy in grief.  
I’ll respect you completely—as you stand, as you plead…  
Your journey beside me, whatever the creed.

She rose at dawn with each new day,
Her laughter danced the airs around,
Light footsteps graced on dew eyed ground.
She sang to chickens, spun fresh bread,
With peppermint thoughts twirling her head,
Fields glanced with gold where sunlight drew—
Daily hymns, a heart ever true.
Beneath bronzed wheat her fine grace lay,
A sturdy muse, pure country May.
Life simple wrought yet colored bold,
As Summer tales by hearth retold.
Oh time may steal the petal youth,
But never bright civility's truth,
A farmer’s wife, laughter’s refrain,
Hums softly through the wind and rain.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Who in his hush of footsteps steals our spring—
A wisp of laughter here, a blushing truth,
The fluttered moments gone on silent wing.
Yet though his hands ache careless through the years,
And trespass gently all that yet is mine,
Sun sweet, I ornament these faded fears
With hope’s bright embroidery, design divine.
He cannot touch the promise inward faced,
Or rob the secret flowers from my heart.
Though outward bloom and flush may halt in haste,
Within remains old magic set apart.
O quiet thief! If youthsoft days must wane,
Teach me to cradle loss and greet the gain.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
He tiptoes through the sunlit webs we spin—
Steals golden hair and laughter from our truth,
Transforms the eager spark that's ours within.
He gathers all the dew our days once wore,
Exchanges innocence for gratitude—
With silent hands he tends a closing door,
Invites reflection’s slower interlude.
But if he seizes bloom, he seeds the mind;  
From loss he coaxes wisdom from the dry.
And when we mourn for things we've left behind,
He paints with gentler hues the passing sky.
O timeworn thief, in your eternal flight,
Leave me the dreams that flutter in the night.

Dwells in the dim at dawn, unseen he stands.
He coaxes blossoms old from precious truth,
And closes plumed dreams in quiet hands.
The hours, once radiant, ghost-shod they slip
So gently few would mourn each vanished day;
Yet youth wears thin—rare nectar, wage and wit—
His silent voice sings color far away.
But what fair petals linger with the grown,
Light polished in the gaze that braves him still?
Though wrinkled bark and root mourn what is gone,
My will seeds faith through fields he cannot till.
Oh subtle reaver! Harvest what you wilt—
There shines in time's thieved wake the gold I've built.

A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,
She danced beneath the skies of May,
With blossoms woven in her hair,
A sunlit smile too bright to bear.
Upon her dress, the daisies lay,
Her laughter rang among the hay,
By scarlet dawns and golden grain,
She twirled unbound, immune to pain.

Her singing called the sparrows close,
She winked at calves beneath the rose,
With nimbleness she filled the shed,
Where cows lay waiting to be fed.
No fortune grand, nor fancy fare,
But shared in love and country air –
So full of hope one glimpse could see
The heart of life’s true poetry.

Now when I have a cold,
Windows shimmer with murky glare; 
Dropped slices of orange and ginger peel
Accumulate on the chilled black slate.
My favorite wool rests on shutters loosely axed, 
Mourning a sunlight intermittent. 
Tea trickles from my lips, refusing any haste –
While memories refuse silence among grey moments. 
Cotton pile towers along the left couch arm,
And time subsides beneath wavering steam.
When I have a cold, muffled ground and drizzle-built gloom
Cocoon distant bells. Rest rushes backward nadir-love
Anchoring me to fevers doused by dawn.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response:
Now when I have a cold
Light drifts lazily around the room
Mute and hesitantly gold  
There’s reverence in every fold
Of blanket pressing foot and knee
Subdued quiet that cradles me   
Everyone speaks in sunlight, sipping tea,
Windowsters softened against a harsher world.  
It doesn’t feel quite lonely, only slow—
Mirrors fogged with song of long ago,
Herbs steep bravely in last night's mug—
Touch turns feverish; thought rugged, snug.  
When the fever clears I’ll join the run, bold.
But there is peace now, when I have a cold.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response:
Now when I have a cold
The world moves softer underneath
Layered lull piled in scarf and sleeve;
Each minted breath delights to hold
Woolen camp beside fogged dreams.
Every cup and quilt seems lovely enough—
Voices resting deeper in hallway hush,
All urgencies repealed, reprieved.
This time measured gently, tea and book adorned,
As distant snowfall grants slow permission
to drift, once abandoned now adored—
Just to be tired, gently forlorn, alone and warmed.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response:
Now when I have a cold
The flat greyness suits me so—
Cat curled at my feet, his drowsy purr
Out-sighing the dribble of wintry rain.
Clouds mark coughs upon window glass
and shush pyjama shuffles down tiled halls.
Bittersweet steam from your scratchy mug of tea
Soft light leaning along quilt and jaw;
I succumb to the slump of ache and pause—
Persimmons plump in the kitchen,
slices like kisses sticking tart to my tongue.
Small kindnesses flare in softened distance,
Dressed in the lull whole afternoons unfold.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

instance_metrics.response:
Now when I have a cold
the house becomes a cello grown still.
Muffled rooms, distant humming fridges—
a resonance made delicate, close as knit mitten to hand.
Looms of water simmer inside silver kettles;
ym patience lands slack, pressed between pillows,
tasting the faint lemon legacy of blue hours.
My thoughts scent winter citrus; imagine wool maps
for eventual recovery, plot furtive blink-sneezes elegance.
Letters and mocha languish, ritual taken slowly—
rescue stitched together with menthol sighs and pale thread.
Wrapped in duvet parliament, memory snoozes.
No fast world, only porridge, Amplitude, cloud.
Cold indeed Guineas, occasionally serene—
you thaw, the closing turn, blanketed but unconsoled,
on dim mornings spiced gently by vagrant breeze–
or the animal wind scuffling outside the sill's dreamy bone.

instance_metrics.response:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the footsteps failed
And ocean-darkness thickened deep inside,
Where hopes whispered but never quite sailed.

A quiet yearning anchors every sigh,
Her heartbeat lost behind a bolted door,
Unafraid, she lets the small moons pass by
While scars unclench the ends of battles sore.

In that drift of dusk deciding what comes next,
She dreams that concealment hums a heavier tune;—
Soft velvet silence veiling her from life's reflex,
As she dwells haplessly with longing for the moon.

But even cloaked behind shadow and shade,
A gentle hope rushes—asking not to be afraid.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

instance_metrics.response:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
While the noisy world presses and tumbles past.
Builds a castle out of pillows, breathing wide
The cool exhale of evening, hoping peace lasts.

Curtains drawn and bolts quietly secured,
Soft blankets queuing in guard at her side—
She drowns all shouts with silence, assured:
A private sphere only she lets decide.

There, comfort floats like sun afloat on dream,
Every noisy worry shrinking in the dust.
Sometimes to hide is to gently redeem—
Even the frightened, beneath frailty's crust
Gather strength to loosen the layers inside:
Each time she hides, part of her learns to stride.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

instance_metrics.response:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To sink beneath the edges of a demanding day,
Then close her laughter, her silent blittled pride,
And tuck away each hope that threatened to stray.

She walks cautious in rooms lined with glass,
Testing the weight of voices speaking over soft grace.
Shaded in corners where shadow-affections pass,
She meets herself with a platemarked face.

What comfort there is: dimness, collect,
Breathing unseen beneath pinned paper stars.
Burden rekindles, but with gentle respect—
To cocoon is to touch softly armored scars.
Each desert retreat quietly bold inside—
She rises anew once she's dared to hide.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Let her presence thinning like dawn mist in the pines,
Air heavy with longing, gentle and wide,
She slips quietly out of her daily confines.

Enfolded in solitude, she sews shadow-quilts,
Patchwork lightning threaded through fathoms unseen,
Awake to her spirit, rinsed of these guilt-tilts—
She savors forgotten places where she’s been.

To dwell undisturbed where small wonders seek,
Unburdened by sunlight or unwelcome designs;
Sometime the heart needs withdraw merely a week—
To find itself whole, slow-stitched in quiet signs.
From deep within veils where brave souls bide,
She grants herself time—sometimes, just to hide.

Restful in darkness, silent as moonbeams.

Untangling the tumult tides that flow.

And hush the sorrow nestled unaware.
Let the dusk cradle fears too deep to keep—
May we find forgiveness if we weep.
Softly the world is quiet, hushed, aware—

Cicadas silenced beneath sky's azure.

instance_metrics.response:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
In battered chest or fading light;
No treasure gentled by a spell,
No legend bound in script or knight.

Perhaps just footprints—woven so
Into the dew’s ephemeral hands;
Or laughter clinging soft as snow,
Buried deep in silver sands.

Maybe only whispered wishes,
Or rain tapping on glass-limned days.
Glimmers crowd the old time-dishes;
What I might be is not what stays.

Whatever fragments fall behind
To line your heart, to teeth or shell—
Hieroglyphs of hope you’ll find;
What I shall leave thee none can tell.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

instance_metrics.response:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
For time removes and rearranges.
An ember, voice, or hollow shell —?
All memories in sunrise changes.

Perhaps a shiver on the skin,
A faded song in drifting air.
The hush before the storms begin,
A shadow you discover there.

No well-scrawled gift, no golden key—
Hearts brand their legacies anew.
The ripple—love bequeathed by me—
Stays out beyond the furthest blue.

Turn gently down the years ahead,
Lift up what sweeps from dusk to bell;
Love not foresworn, nor vow that’s fled—
What I shall leave thee, none can tell.

What I shall leave thee none can tell—  
Perhaps but silk of laughter, spilled,

Not lock or locket, lettered claim,

What I shall leave thee none can tell—  
A comet’s tail, a faded Spring,  
A half-remembered citadel  
Where distant bells and swallow sing.

Perhaps mere shadows at noontide,  
Redeemed in pools of rain and light;  
Or the crisp hush left where hope sighed—  
A secret waited far from sight.

Knotted to larks’ ascending flights,

What I shall pledge, then say farewell?

instance_metrics.response:
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Cogs revolve in quiet sweep,
Dawn whispers pale at window’s edge,
Shadows learn the everyday pledge:
Up with a groan, toes on cold tile,
Surge to the grind single file.
Coffee beguiles, subway shoves,
Day pressed flat with shoulds and must-loves.
Return at dusk to silent rooms-
Clatter of dishes, vacuumed glooms.
Retreat to arms, collapse so deep—
Hello again, you weary sleep.
But somewhere beneath routines repeat,
Storm-awake heart skips its secret beat,
Calling questions loud in our heads:
Are we living, or waking dead?
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
This daily rhythm soft and deep;
Yet seasons slip all swift and slow,
In little footsteps I barely know.
Sunrise pounds the windows thin,
Coffee sings upon my skin.
Errands passing like a stream,—
Children’s laughter, distant dream.
When twilight tides the sky to blue,
Dinner dances in fading hue.
Sink the daylight softly, steep:
Another round—wake, work, home, eat, sleep.
Yet in tired moments bravely grown,
Hope calls softly, not unknown.
Ready still to search or keep—
Find more than just wake, work, home, eat, sleep.

Yet somewhere beneath clock’s tight sweep,

A poet loses his power for poetry—  
Where once the world unraveled, letter by line,  
Just ash of verbs warms his memory,  
Ideas press their blooms in salt and brine.

He’s a silent architect of unbuilt verse,  
A shadow strayed from ink’s holy design,  
Words unravel before their birth—  
Language recoils, starved along the spine.

Perhaps one night, a breeze will murmur through,  
A waking syllable—a color shot with light.  
But now, northern windows sighed with dew,  
Turning drums’s echo into quiet night.

A poet loses his power for poetry—  
Calling muses, clutching echoes in vein.  
Origami syllables, they once danced free;  
Now folded scripts tumble lost, again.

Fingers tapger the vacant drum of a table,  
Searching pages for ink that loves the quill.  
All brilliance, ceasing—quiet and unable;  
A meadow dormant despite the sun’s will.

Yet seeds resist demand or outstretched plea.  
Patience, poet—restraint can also be art.  
Let the stillness nurture whatever the next line will be:  
The heart waits in silence, to quicken its start.

In shadowed dusk the poet sits—bereft,
Hand poised above the emptiness of sheets.
A silent ache where cadence once had cleft,
The light around his longing now retreats.

Words desert his tongue, old visions wane;
His torch of longing guttered by the breeze.
White lilies grown between him and his pain—
Gestures die quiet under trembling trees.

But in that web of loss where longing weaves,
Power is scattered like thistledown apart.
Broken tools may cede, yet belief retrieves
Language from quiet scars inside the heart.

Let him wait, battered by silent alarms:
Lost power may journey the world—to return as psalms.

A shadow cast where sun-warmed meadows dwell.
Upon the tides and tempests, still he sees
The steady lamp of peace flicker with the breeze.

Soft-patched with hope where sorrow once had been.
No shaking ground beneath these sanctuary walls—
Each prayer unearths heaven whenever it calls.

He gathers every wish in evening mist,
Countless as stars, by mystery kissed,
Harbor amid harm, sure anchor of the soul.
Saints come weary; in rest, rejoice—made whole.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

instance_metrics.response:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Slipping softly into shade’s forgiving arms.
She builds a sanctuary, deep inside,
Safe from the crowd and daylight noise, untouched by charm.
Trouble drifts behind shifting curtains, vaguely known—
Such comfort gathers where her hush applies.
Let silence fill the pages overgrown;
Let quiet collect in long, unspoken sighs.
And if she slips, just out of sight of day,
Perhaps, inside this wrapped cocoon she’s braver.
Outside will wait; she calls no debts to pay—
Private peace worth moments she can savor.

instance_metrics.response:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
Fog rises before the day begins beyond glass towers,
A touch spectral, like longing filtering through trembling neon dusk.
You linger in canyons of crowd and idle lights;
I wander leaf-hushing promenades the color of unspoken words.

Your imagined laughter beats like traffic far toward dawn.
In splinters of laughter and cement geography
I shape rooftops near purple-tulip mass, hearing your secret presence—
Swallowed requests spurred by buses scrawling through messages.

And so love walks these slow boulevards:
you return in afternoon cobblestone,
or lean soft above streetcar tracks—
The day accepts an ache: there are nights when the city holds you close,
Mirages and wind blended gentle, until absence wears your face beyond morning’s rise.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

instance_metrics.response:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
Lamplight-length shadows haunt rivers of glass where taxis shift,
The city exhales, spent and silvered—we share in its hush.
Sidewalks, dressed in strangers’ reflections, reciprocate histories:
Timid hunger sailing between flickers at fog-screened intersections,
Holding tight to a name blossoming unspoken.

Coffee steam rises from tabletops carved by separate mornings, and yet,
I catch dreams in windowpanes where your face disappears round corners.
Rain summons our past with tangerine pulses across concrete skin
Urging—hold on. Finds me searching cadence under billboard moons,
Construing verses out of every old brick and knowable bruise,
Finding anew the freedom to begin—as once in the city,
In which I love you, silence repairs memory’s rind.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

instance_metrics.response:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
Where midnight lusters damp bridges in memory’s silk,
My heart turns restless with gull-flown longing in smokestreaked dark.
Your voice echoes between windows sealed by brief winter light.
Within summer avenues—ghostblossom and train-song—I wait,
Clasping time dropping petal fingerprints into alley sconces.

In battered cafes, stories spool live on table edges—
I summon courage to carve syllables secret onto day bakers’ waxed packets.
So compassed by faded stars, our love finds fresh ruin and shining undoing;
Each morning blooms irrepressible forgiveness set freely unforeseen.
The river carries sleepless hope beneath ouroboros highways—
So, finally, in the city echoing you, love walks on, half-dream, most real.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

instance_metrics.response:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
My footsteps compose secret languages upon battered stone,
Each busker strumming blue constellations on copper corners—a hymn raining out hope.
There, balconies bloom in plastered distances,
Open boulevards inscribe your laughter along their restless dusk; this rib-ringing tide finds its sky reflected beneath river bridges whetted with prayers.

Graffiti tangles truth and tribute—that name, your name, crowning brickwork bright as chapel glass—it writhes alive in taxi taillight winks and accidental whispers at snow-marrowed bars.
Into sirens, pigeons, velvet morning routines, the fragrance stirs myths I cherished of your ordinary: lovers twined at weekends edgewise, a glimpse in mirrored shopfront sighs—a cityheart yearning you a sanctuary.

So when cold seed-thick night falls, threadbare courage in eyelids spans towers limned shadows:
‘Here, here’—my spirit says, ‘this city is my open palm: witness all these days—no less beloved because you are not near—empyreal, haunted beautifully, by you.’

instance_metrics.response:
That's my window. This minute—
Mist hovers against the pane like old cotton,
daylight toyed out, humming low.
This minute leaks from the blossom of my breath—
yellowed and alive, the square opening waits,
suburbs bristling gently beyond wavy glass.
Somewhere, the neighbor's curtain flutters a promise,
the moment stays, shy-boned and blue-fingered,
a level spill of sense quieted on the malty stride—
inside, in daylight's sharp balloon, everything holds;
traces of who passed, reflected half, then gone—
Each unhurried second clings in drop and ripple:
Amenities, June sparrows—all songs face west—
I gather it where it forms: gentle as minute dust,
oh, let the light crowd always my window
—just now, and just like this.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

instance_metrics.response:
That's my window. This minute,
a round gold coin of morning relayed
across unlit wood and panes,
tender blue pressed against glass—
one minute slick with warmth and old stories,
cmp anywhere, fine as quartz loam, clean suspense.
A neighbor laughs—slant-wing words thicker than dew,
first strolls rise beneath banished stars.
Traffic cranes distant evening hopes,
wishes newly grown against city edge blurs.
Sawtooth skies—full but unattached—
All of it becomes mine:
the brittle framing, seeded haze, careful hush
stoking some recalled bravery. And if
audents render quietly in bright tune—
imagine finding peace where light suspends,
on morning melted bare and slow
That's my window. These minutes never hide.

instance_metrics.response:
That's my window. This minute—
Light angles itself across the room,
Lifting dust in city air. Something pauses,
Life anew chewing choice, nibbling dreams at sill and frame.
Outside, trees confide in street-level breeze; dogs press their case
To awaken strangers wrapped in crash and cool vapor sigh.
Weightlessly, now, with the span of glass.
You stare—to sanctum, to void, to layer.
Clouds flag easy kingdoms for passing planes; a neighbor's laughter trips jangled silver.
I somehow own all I can see, this singular shallow wide breadth.
I notice the molecules here: in this gathered—a window marking the minute,
Where I belong, and have belonged, silently—uncountable grains of morning.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

instance_metrics.response:
That's my window. This minute,
the world leans in with golden arms,
sprawls gentle heat against pale drawn curtains,
rustles ambition in the city above the calm.
Sparrows spill light daring the ledge,
each pulse on glass a tune reminder that this hour is whole.
Spinning through laundry lines and breakfast smoke,
people passing quickly, pressing time, never seeing stillness spars with wind.
I breathe—the distance narrows between frame and face,
thin sugars of warmth hiding a thousand glimmers thus won.
In this hush, for now, I hope through panes;
small and waiting—each minute holding my name like waiting rain.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

instance_metrics.response:
That's my window. This minute/drinks quietly from the edge of morning—a thick silence, watered by suspense. Shadows arrange pilgrim huts along the worn wallpaper while pulse beats soft beneath distance. Out there, pedals whirr. Butterflies negotiate traffic’s mindless distillation. In here, jasmines itinerate through glass cooled breath, swirling towards the bow where dreams met insects just retiring.

Every second tastes closer, stands barefoot and dares me across sills and rails. If blue leaks hospitality down the stucco curve, the day releases its routine mask. You don’t see but that rectangle anchors hours, reporting moonfeather resting, rabbitstars worrying weed chinks.

Nothing wants repeating but this—light flickering brave atop mane, pigeons chafing announcements in fragile percussion. I mend the canvas by remembering: my window—this world/minute—once. Radiance naturalizes regret and the city unfolds within my gaze—one promise/and pause of today breathing still under the clean crown of glass.

instance_metrics.response:
In my first sleep the world stood still at dawn,
Quiet shadows gently brushed my lips to gray,
Old dreams moved closely, wrapped me like warm lawn,
As ember time tip-toed asteroid clichés.

My childhood voice whispered river-run tunes;
The midnight owl called to silken, waking day.
The moon rested, swollen amid my marooned
Quickening breath and star-cast, weightless sway.

In my first sleep arises a cradle-old hush,
I traverse seas of memory too soft to keep—
Here midnight wears petals of innocent blush,
And morning worlds glaze back through my first sleep.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
In my first sleep I traveled beyond my shell,
Where mists-erased months curled softly on afternoon knees,
The hush overhead a cradle-song's spell,
Bathed in rust tones bleak with sweet unease.

No sorrow stalked the player of my first dream,
Light planted silver coins over the arid plain,
Promise-scent blurred reality’s cold seam,
And gently circled fear from sight and lane.

In my first sleep, I walked for the very first time each dawn.
Tranquil as wild grass slips earthbound and gone.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

In my first sleep, a hush fell thick as dawn,
I drifted soundless under velvet weave,
With nothing named and nothing thus withdrawn,
Just constellations I dreamed I'd conceive.

My thoughts like dust motes slid among the wheat,
Ancestor echoes distant, dim—well spun—
Unfurl inside sorrows the stones repeat;
Tides slowed, earthwaiting sense, battle undone.

In my first sleep—origin without frame—
Mystery passed over womb and star, unseen flame.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
In my first sleep I stirred beneath a silver tree,
The night cool with possibility and not regret;
Up through cradling branches I could not yet see,
But wind leaning forward said: ''remember, not yet.''

Pillowed in beginnings before burden or name,
Bold heart curved to nebulae not marked before dawn.
German-eyed gold bordered dreams unreclaimed—a flame–
We all begin. My first sleep is all of us, spun strong.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

instance_metrics.response:
In my first sleep, the world washed softly over me,
Like the turning tide in a shell, memory indistinct,
Serene, tides of turquoise possibility lie undiscovered—
No worries, no weight from the land of afterthought.

Whispers of worlds that might never awake
Swirled slow in my cradle sky, infinite
As moth-light touching closed eyelids; aching not for years
I had not lived nor lives unopened yet.

All joy sifted silent, every sorrow unborn,
Through the hourglass whose bottom page was unturned;
In my first sleep I swam nameless, before true night,
Humble, unfurling with sunrise outside my sight.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter hearty, hands calloused tough,
Beneath coarse garments, honest souls hid,
Kindled by truth plain words would rid.

Whisky and rhyme as kind companions danced
In smoky taverns of Scottish expanse,
Each tale spun of fire and rain and moors,
Wrapped in melody forever endures.

Hard men who hunched through mud and heather,
Bonded not by blood, but by Scottish weather—
Yet poets they birthed, from hardship sprung love,
In rustic verses or dreams thereof.

He spoke—so we listen for voices strong,
In whiskeyed note, in emboldened song:
For poetry blooms not from the tamed,
But men rude and rough—untouched, unnamed.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

instance_metrics.response:
He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough;
Of soils unbroken, destinies tough,
Wide fields where plough turned ancient ground,
And laughter from ale-soaked mouths resound.

They stamped the earth down with weathered feet,
Spoke words ferocious and bittersweet—
Eggshells of pride, yolks of regret,
Hard loves immortal, a father’s debt.

But in the smoke and wild refrain,
Burns heard their plea and eased their pain;
In verses carved as wind-carved stone,
Their heartsarding joys became his own.

He spoke of men untouched by creams—
Save hoarfrost blown through dusky dreams—
In rough regard bade us behold:
From rugged bitter clay springs gold.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough—  
Unthroned enliveners dancing through the trough  
Of coalfired towns and furrowed fields,  
With honest words their comfort yields.  
  
A scythe in hand, a whiskey by breast,  
Doing their proud poverty best,  
Laughter and storm roused by birr—not bluff;  
Yet find in lines glints pure enough.  
  
For under scorned crust, gold kindly homes,  
Generous hearts in cottages close,  
Warmed in rebellion or ruined by drought,  
Still audacious in hope and humble in doubt.  
  
He spoke—and silence grew full and awake:  
Within rough men Burns mirrors make.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,  
Weathered by time, sharpened by fate.
Words with the grit of the stony bluff,  
Voices rolling sudden and late.
  
Callused hands trembling tender song,
Beneath the grime, a longing shines.
For camaraderie, old and long,
As kind red gleams in Scottish wines.

Here in a tavern’s croft they dwell
Birthing ballads from broken laugh,
Often misunderstood as well—
Such gold can sound earthy and half.

He spoke, and the room autumn-leaf still,
Touched by Burns’ men with iron will.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough—
Through peat-black nights with collar upturned,
They trudge old roads stitched from storm and scrub;
Yet listen: beneath that coarse veneer, a spirit burned.

Gaunt fingers twine round battered flasks,
Their laughter sudden, breaking fens of gloom; 
Unwritten sons of Scotland’s mast and mastiff,
With poetry caught between hand and loom.

Burns knew their marrow—their defiant jest,
And longing bound hard into a simple verse.
O-rude disciple, O-rough rest, embodiment
Of lives relentless, both gift and curse.

From stone-walled fields to forsaken inns of peat,
They render music stern and sow love beneath their feet.

Shall I, wasting in despair, 
Count the hours lost to regret,
Shadows gather, none aware
Of dreams with edges still unmet?
Yet winds aloft whisper anew
Of light behind long-coated storm.
Drying these fragments, pearls of dew—
With trembling hands, I shape my form.
For despair, a siren, at my side,
But hope strums sweet on whispering breeze,
Not all is lost; gray can’t deride
A heart determined woe to ease.
Day drains darkness drop by line,
So shall I waste, or seek the shine?

instance_metrics.response:
Shall I, wasting in despair,
Watch the inching of the sun,
Broken glass in faded air,
Memories scattering, one by one?
No! Let not sorrow sketch my name
Upon pale sheets or dusk’s embrace,
For while desire still lights a flame,
Hope blooms patient in her space.
Gentle hours, turn anew,
Withdraw your doubt and whispered chill—
Love walks and calls me from blue;
Despair forgone, where’s joy’s thrill?
If shadow asks that I reside,
Let hallways of my heart decide.

Shall I wasting in despair,
Fade with evening’s willow air,
Pin envy on each bloom’s new cheek,
Silent where the bramble speak?
Let storms rebuke, let night mislead,
Still not in sorrow shall I bleed.
Let struggle shape and gently pare—
Roses sometimes bloom from care.
A life unlived, behind safe glass,
Resists the passion wild seas pass;
So if a tempest leans my sprit,
Seeded longing birthed from it,
I will gather despair, set it to flight,
Hearten the ruin—forge morning from night.

Shall I wasting in despair,
Lose myself to empty cries?
Upon lake’s mirroring stare,
See yesterday become disguise.

Each sorrow sown calls joy again,

If despair, too, deep may go—

Let me instead with kindness sow
Sunlit pieces, strained and whole.
From scattering dusk, let hearts repair;
No, never lost, while I still dare.

light pours unexpected, tender through dots of glass,
each speck and pause minting horizon fresh;
a city insistently wonders outside,
still in its tousled dressing gown,

instance_metrics.response:
A poet loses his power for poetry—  
Ink dries at the bend of his wrist.  
The careful cadence, dip and sweep,  
of timber spun by flickering light, resist.  
Tongue once fluent dissolves to silence,  
and in place of brilliance, dregs accumulate;  
words gather at the door unnoticed, unseen,  
birds without songs halted—forlorn is their fate.  
In the hush that follows, memories echo faint:  
tales unwritten drift somewhere out of reach.  
He scans empty fields of a fallow mind,  
truths crumbling, thoughts tattered, themes leached.  
Yet maybe, within such vacant dark—a renewal start.  
When absence soaks deep, yearning grows anew;  
another voice trembling behind closed eyes,  
to one day restore the Eden he once knew.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

instance_metrics.response:
A poet loses his power for poetry—  
How empty grow the evenings once spun with gold,  
As paper awaits in vain and the fingers grow cold.  
The orchards of melody close trembling gates,  
No wind weaves rhythms, no syllable invades.  
Each sunrise beckons silence, once tender and kind,  
While hunger shivers in the well of the mind.  
He stares at the silence pooling thick across dawn,  
Mocks ink—servant now tyrant—remains withdrawn.  
Flown is the wing that ferried ink lore,  
No muse taps sudden; lines stumble to the floor.  
Yet as darkness breeds loneliness, furrows the soul,  
Perhaps loss transforms—each void hems fidelity's role.  
and someday the heart, freed scant by its ache,  
Might birth slant beginnings new verses could make.

instance_metrics.response:
A poet loses his power for poetry—
His mind, once honeycombed with words, anonymous fragrance,
brewing stanzas beneath silent dusk,
ers now abide only the patient ghosts.
Hands cocoon-empty, rhythm unmoored,
he listens—long—hoping for language to trickle,
finding quiet vastness instead of lines.
Light cracks across unblemished paper,
it means nothing: blankness joins, entwines.
Yet outside, lilacs fatten, spring is not suspended—
how heavily the futile goddess leans upon his brow.
His voice, so certain, split sparrows from shadow:
Gone ringing away into mute unknowable now.
Might loneliness tug his lost stanza home again,
Or will silence be his cordless mastery,
Ruling where cadence once dined,
A heart at rest, distant dream no melody will define.

Tongue tangled in invisible thread.
Every sight and sound now passes quietly,

Yet he walks: through gstured mornings,

What is absence, if not old abundance disguised?
Will feeling one dusk press through his veins—
Stir,new inspiration from long-sealed rooms?
A hushed hope lingers, he listens and swoons,
Dreaming that power is slumber, not doom.

Steel forged by fire, now whispered shadow-startling,
Unspooling ribbons over sleeping ground—
A breathless hush lit only by the sound.

Moons glance off faces pressed to foggy glass,
Wondering at places meant purely to pass.
Power surges, engines sing harsh and low;
Guided by timetables, into the unknown they go.

One by one each town flickers and slides behind,
While the future glimmers certain, unwavering, unsigned.
Promise breaks open: stars ripple through the hearting,
That flows with hope, like the train in the deep night darting.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing silence rangy, under sky-furrowed and stark.
Hoarse metal bound for elsewheres only knows its starting,
hissing cold promise in tendons lit with a spark.

Passengers doze dreamspun behind pane-reflected eyes,
Gone hurried centuries swirl past bare hills, dim and thin.
Luminescent rash rebukes, flickers—then softly dies—
Each station a stitch through night unraveling again.

Watch the distance narrow, unsheathing rails and sleep—
Journeyward arrows fly—threading secrets too deep.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their Clydeside toil, their passion pressed      
Against the stubborn molding clough—
Strong speech and hearts ill-confessed.

Lank fingers red from steady tools,
With muscles tuned to barrel chime;
Their tempers worn sharp and cool,
Too earnest for a quieter time.

Yet under scars—wild Northern breath—
The oath, the argument, the jest—
We find—the warm and wondering depth
Of yearnings avidly expressed.

So sing they still in rye-lit homes—
Their loud rough lives a poet woofs:
He spoke of Burns; and, leaf and loam,
Men bloom fierce hope from fielded roofs.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
With wind-blown brows and working hands;
Who scraped their living earnestly enough,
Furrowing fields and troubling loam-bound lands.

He knew them well, with talk unsmooth,
Unpracticed in the gentle art of grace;
But shining in sincerity and truth,
The earnest worry haunted on each face.

Yet song would rise above the marsh and glen,
Unpolished hearts would tremble just like leaves;
From men who tilled, not lords nor careful pen,
Fell words that even heaven can believe.

O poet! You saw with sympathetic fire,
Roughness as root, but beauty as attire.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough—  
Whose hands bore witness to turning soil,  
Labor-stained voices harsh, yet not enough  
To dim a generous heart within the toil.  
  
Whisky laughter, barefoot oaths at dawn—  
Yet tangled in their warming tongues, a want  
To loosen solitude as night slips on,  
Dreaming letters alight, illustrious and gaunt.  
  
In low-hewn rooms with flickered lantern light,  
They’d judge and jest of weather, laird, and birth;  
Yet trembled, awed, at lines so bold and bright,  
Still haunted with the troubled hope of earth.  
  
So echo now with every toiling breath  
Those gruff old voices clasped from mist and heath.

Fiercely honest as midsummer rain,

Farmers and craftsmen, crude at heart,

Cottage hearthlight on freckled brows,  
Ale-muddled laughter beneath the moon,  
In roundelay and ploughed-up vows

She lies alone upon her bed,
Moon-silver tangled in her hair,

Like autumn leaves that scent the air.

While silent dreams entwine her sleep,

Lonely, tender—heart unraveled,
Light awake in dark despair;
She maps past journeys never traveled,
With every breath she takes the dare.

Somewhere beyond these restless hours
Daybreak awaits to heal and mend,
But now within fate’s fragile towers,
Alone she lies—a floating friend.

I weep—a lone cathedral filled,
My tears escape, escape, silently spilled.
Raindrops racing to be gone
Shimmering artifacts, vanishing at dawn.
There was a comfort I could claim in sorrow,
Collecting each pearl for tomorrow.
But now when grief overtakes a fragile pride,
I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
Like rivers denied their banks,
Emotions slip, no appreciable thanks.
Are these cast-off drops even mine,
If none remain at the end of my line?
Heaven gathers what I lose in rain,
My cheeks once witnesses, barren in their pain.
Still—when I cry in this endless divide,
Nothing lingers; the tears don't stay by my side.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

instance_metrics.response:
Of all the things I'd hoped to keep, emotion undisguised,
I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
Running fast as streams through hollows in stone,
They vanish mid-journey, leaving me alone.
Wet traces do not comfort, nor hands steel braced,
They're gone, these childlike tears, dissolve in haste.
Silent vapor ghosts abscond from my eyes—
Raw longing unclaimed though sorrow never lies.
Empty, unwilling expatriates of the soul,
Even sadness slips helpless past pity’s control.
So I wander through anguish, longing to confide—
But when I cry, the tears won't even stay by my side.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love—
Each shadow on the evening pavement swept
Unfolds the memories woven tightly above,
Their quiet promise gently in my pocket kept.
The gentle wildflowers bow beneath soft rains,

A scent, a song that distance can’t explain,
A touch that silence never could impair.
With every solitary step I trace my longing,
Your face, your voice aglow within the gloom,
Reminding me, despite this nighttime’s haunting:
In emptiness, your absence dares to bloom.
So let me walk, the stars our silent envoy—
Where solitude, my love for you, employs.

No polished tongue, no decorum cloaked,

The rugged men, as rough as need,

Safe harbor, anchors, winds dulce gone, the squall behind us laid.
And yet, the roots yearn upward too, for what the clouds become,
Those wary of the dull resolve enchantment’s smoldering glade.

For hope is forged beyond that gate with walls unlatched and wide:
In change’s churning whitespace, the marrow whirls anew—
While settlers’ hearts grow timorous from silences, resigned,
The hope recites fierce metaphors unsheltered by what’s true.

Thus cherish restless questions, keep borders gapped by wonder—
For while we wish thinning edges would scout some tranquil chart,
Spring seeds know no advance—the wild, unmottled lore—
How only stirred souls stir the earth and quicken every start.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
People want the earth steady beneath their feet,
and warm lamp light to crown their every night.
They ask for edges to line a day—
squares to color lives swiftly neat.

Yet between roots and uprooting is where new green seethes:
Unsettled, a murmur of hope lifts the world like spring,
alive in soils remade by disruption, forged in uncertainty—
hearts learning to trust the tremor over each gentle thing.

Hold joy as a fleeting guest within changing rooms,
and see how madness and marvel in their whirlwind restore faith.
People wish to be settled; still, let us exult in the drift and the roam:
ous prayers of becoming, our wandering paragraphs of hope.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
People thirst for fixtures, safety pressed in stone:
For seasoned chairs beneath old ceilings, days unworked, well known.
Yet roots run shallow where still soil is settled in a pall;
Unrest—a shaking wind—proclaims a wakened call.

While breaths soothe and pillows give their nod toward night,
Hope cannot nest in habits spun too tight.
For only unsettled hearts, unrouted by fear,
Traverse strangeness, grow larger with each coming year.

The old daily pulse dulls, whispering dreams away,
Wish steadfast silence losses ever stray.
So yield to revealings, abandoned for the breeze—
It’s the unsettlement that quietly sets us free.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
We long for anchor, steady ground—the velvet clasp of light.
Words planted in routines, a hearth resilient through the storm.
Yet beneath still waters, bright longing’s swarm:
Hope’s fiercest blooms unroot themselves and rise inside the night.

Settle, but not quite: disquiet&tremors break safe floors.
Outpaces wait ahead, unexpected gifts and one wild door.
Footsteps crack quiet ice, new patterns in cold unknowns—
Only aimless statelessness finds life grown.

As we fumble for lasting outline through shifting inner lands,
Know uncertainty is grace, held hungry in trembling hands.
Hope—richest fever—looms nearer each storm spent:
In unsettlement, life’s map less drawn, shoes muddied—with hope well meant.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
We build walls from routine—cling tight to all we know,
Dream of lantern-lit windows under orderly rows.
But each brick laid in comfort muffles future’s seedling song;
The hands that softly settle seldom reach what makes them strong.

Give me cracks and thunder, discord among the pews—
Elevation grows from earthquakes—not from sunset’s warm reuse.
Courting fierce unease, I chase the wind unsettled,
In restlessness find hope inscribed by wings dismantled.

If peace is a water surface complete in its cold role,
Hope is wake behind the prow, motion stirring “whole.”
Bend towards that brightness beckoning from an inward caravan:
Living’s tallest marvel waits beyond what’s safely planned.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

instance_metrics.response:
At the highways of woes where the night pours in,
Shadows unfurl in the wash of headlamps,
Engine hums courting distant hearts,
and signposts fallen face-first with despair read No Arrival, No Return.
Tightly wound, threads spun of memory and what can't be mended,
danegeld for cars ferrying past mistakes beneath guttering moons—
mourning exchanging pale coins for passage inward.
Here each turn curves sorrow's endless loop,
dust warm with the ghost feet swept through reveille ashes—
yet still, trembling willows lean hopeward to storms’ hushed aftermath.
Is it lament,
is it hunger universal as tired orbits?
Consolation seems ragged as dawn advancing too soon,
yet onward must we, hearts oiled with yearning, roll.
So meet me, nigh companion, when roads cross 
beyond those devouring highways—
where patience, unzipped, glows reckless at the threshold light of healing.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

instance_metrics.response:
At the highways of woes where deadened traffic rolls,
Anguish streams like dusk thunder beneath hemming sky,
Billboards wobble slogans of chances plastered thin,
Gravel mourns under near and weakening resolve.
Nighthawks chase ruts alit by passing parades of headlights—a semaphore of pain.
Caravans of sorrow, waiting for green lights never crowned with hope.
Entrusted hearts drift vacant, turn south onto memory’s briar-red lanes,
Metal rails ring grim ballads older than sorrow—a brass cord stung with longing,
But solace, faint and fluttering, splits midnight headlights,
Gathering grace in shelter:
one halted mile at a stop—in pause, 
outpours silver traces boldly grooved onto break-of-dawn faith.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

At the highways of woes I wander alone,
Past tangled embankments grown wild from old pain.
Telegraph wires sing grievances out of tone,
Their songs, blue with heartbreak, lacing the rain.
Dust sheets the guardrails where memories roam;
Tires hush quiet where joy bled out thin;
Exit signs flicker their perishing hope—
Nameless and grieved where no future begins.
Yet I walk roads parcelled in longing’s bright dregs,
A gathering hush swirling round silent bends,
While dawn’s pale luster caresses rueful legs,
Cleansing the grayscale from each bitter end.
Staffed by new will and an eye for sun’s prose,
I emerge beyond borders—the highways of woes.

At the highways of woes, I heard the mournful rye sway
in the tempo of restless coins and gravel hearts.

drained by the spill of cars grinding aimless in neon decay.
Every sign a promise wilted—left like pamphlets unread,
every mile pressed deeper into a sediment of old failures.
Still, onward I inch, a silhouette outrageously brave or bereft,
adorned with hauntings in knotted scarves and petrol angel wings.
Starlings swirl over cracked tar, sermonizing in wheeling flocks—
testaments scrawled over clouds, forgiving the unatoned maze below.
Someday, these bruised ribbons yield
spare light or song, not just exile rolled tight under yearning tread.

ten thousand taillights chase the glisten of remainders—

I swim slow seas of remembrance, concrete-mapped and threadbare,
mirroring rain-weep upon windbroken median grass.
Every stumbled detour siphons laughter once unopened,
darling names locked under chrome rattles and fog thumbprints.
Herons watch luckless dreams idle at offramps bearing whispered apologies:
human cargo, battered bright by endless yearning,
carries rag-saffron spirits beyond overlooks lost to view,
stitching lonesome navigation into routes unmarked but seeking grace.
Must woe be these torque-tight lanes and brake-lit delays?

map folded in upon itself as if never written?

at highway’s far trembling, sorrow blooms wild out of steel.

Through me, you pass into the city of woe,
Where faded voices shape the silent cold;
I walk the cinder dusk the ancients know,
On sorrow’s threshold, desperate, darkness-sold.

Here twilight sings in endless borrowed breath,
Stone arches lean with nameless, numbered pain;
Erased from hope, apprentice unto death—
Only the shadowed path and iron rain.

Still—hidden embers flicker deep beneath,
Reminding all that sorrow breaks, then forms.
There burns in ash a stubborn, flickering wreath,
Hope scarred but persistent through hopeless storms.
‘Per me si va nella citta dolente,’ draws where courage hesitates
to fight lamented cause.

icu city opens and none breathe in but guilt and hope’s milk.

night presses olive alleys, mouth tasting dust—

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
Silent muse of my days, extinguished light.  
Too soon unthreaded from life's sacred spool,  
A gentle laugh echoing from distant night.  
I trace the imprint of your song on clay,  
Grasping remembrances that tumble and teem,  
Sweet fragments clustered like dew on the rye,  
The heartbeat fading—yet alive in my dream.  
Time, relentless courier—thief bereft,  
Steals laughter, mirth, all innocent design,  
Leaving but wisps of softly uttered prayers,  
My silent hands held out to hold the line.  
Still, I remember hollyhock-stained palms,  
A name—a laughter's spill, a promise kept.  
Dear vanished comfort, vessel wrought for calm,  
Farewell—the child of joy whom dewdew swept.

A grief distilled as fragrance from our pains,  
A memory cradled in parental trust.  
  
Child of my right hand, and all my heart’s employ;

She lies alone upon her bed,

Beneath her fragile, quiet skin.

Across these sheets of old desire;
Now hours fold into her frame,
Sweet echoes changed, and just her name.

She closes weary, searching eyes
Beyond this room, beyond the ties
Of waking hope too frail to rise—
She lies alone, and dreaming lies.

How can you grieve and express loss?  
Beneath the quiet hush of troubled hours,  
Tears tremble in the iris of the dawn.  
Hands reach softly to the place, now vacant,
Gathering fragments memory has drawn.
Yet language stumbles over empty spaces,
The weight of words, impossible to weigh;
Grief drifts, unwilling shadow, through the moments,
Longing to shape in clay what time does fray.
In notes untuned, you hum a song remembered;
Your shadow cradles echo of their voice.
Silence becomes a ritual you carry,
And sorrow, uninvited guest—your choice.
So honor love that pain cannot distort:
Grieving is the garden; tears, the tender art.

How can you grieve and express loss?
Is it the hush that lingers after laughter fades,
Soft hands gripping whispers in lamplit rooms?
Sometimes, loss is language caught behind old teeth,
Refusing to bite through or simply slip away.

Or perhaps it's your name muttered into bruised dusk,
An offering the white stars would cradle, if they could.

You pour loss in ink, in kindles of wordless cries;
Grow gardens with stones that say hello but long to say goodbye.
Knowing—comfort comes softly,
Not as cure, but slow salve rising pretty as morning fog:
Every tear a tribute to love that once learned to stay.
